summary: FBI interview transcript with Tammy Hill-McFadden, a former Deutsche Bank AML compliance officer, detailing her concerns about the bank's handling of high-risk clients including Jeffrey Epstein, Jared Kushner, and Donald Trump, and alleging retaliation by management for raising compliance issues.

persons.name: Tammy Hill-McFadden
persons.role: Former Deutsche Bank AML Compliance Officer / KYC Manager
persons.context: Primary interviewee providing information about Deutsche Bank's compliance practices, specifically regarding high-risk accounts like Jeffrey Epstein's and Jared Kushner's. She alleges retaliation for raising concerns.

persons.name: Kristen Doolittle
persons.context: Attorney present during Hill-McFadden's FBI interview.

persons.name: Brian McCafferty
persons.context: Attorney present during Hill-McFadden's FBI interview.

persons.name: Zanaib
persons.context: Senior Vice President in New York who applied pressure to open accounts quickly.

persons.name: Elenita Escobar
persons.context: Part of Hill-McFadden's chain of command in New York when she was a KYC Manager.

persons.name: Steve Hellinger
persons.context: Part of Hill-McFadden's chain of command in New York when she was a KYC Manager.

persons.name: Paul Kavanaugh
persons.context: Part of Hill-McFadden's chain of command in New York when she was a KYC Manager.

persons.name: Clarrisa Delafuente
persons.context: Hill-McFadden's initial supervisor when she became an AML Compliance Officer. Provided a formula that revealed deferred PEP cases.

persons.name: Almarie Worlds
persons.context: Fellow AML Compliance Officer based in Jacksonville, FL.

persons.name: Ying Wang
persons.context: AML Compliance Officer based in New York. Placed 102 PEP cases into deferred status.

persons.name: Yang Wong
persons.context: AML Compliance Officer based in New York.

persons.name: Michelle Gabriel
persons.context: Added to the Jacksonville, FL compliance team.

persons.name: Kevin Wilson
persons.context: Added to the Jacksonville, FL compliance team.

persons.name: Danya Friedman
persons.context: Added to the Jacksonville, FL compliance team.

persons.name: Cripa Apal
persons.context: Added to the Jacksonville, FL compliance team.

persons.name: Sheri Quigley
persons.context: Took over as Hill-McFadden's supervisor in 2015. Described as incompetent and retaliatory. Made decisions on internal SARs and rejected Hill-McFadden's work.

persons.name: Wayne Salit
persons.context: Quigley's supervisor. Involved in decisions on filing SARs and the Jared Kushner case. Did not respond to Hill-McFadden's complaint about Quigley.

persons.name: Doug Sloan
persons.context: Along with Salit, determined whether to file SARs with FinCEN.

persons.name: Francesca Benson
persons.context: HR representative who opened an investigation into Hill-McFadden's complaint about Quigley.

persons.name: Joseph Acedebo
persons.context: Continued to allow Quigley to write Hill-McFadden's performance reviews despite knowing of the conflict. Supported Quigley and Salit.

persons.name: Josh Blazer
persons.context: Hill-McFadden expressed her issues and desire to transfer to him, but nothing resulted. Was present at her termination meeting.

persons.name: Jared Kushner
persons.context: Owner of the LLC 'Real Contrad,' whose account showed suspicious cryptocurrency transactions that Hill-McFadden flagged.

persons.name: Rose
persons.context: Relationship manager for both Jared Kushner's and Jeffrey Epstein's accounts. Contacted Kushner's company regarding flagged transactions, contrary to policy.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to his old post office portfolio cases where the origin of funds was unclear.

persons.name: Erica Prada
persons.context: Present at a meeting with Hill-McFadden and Quigley.

persons.name: Marla Liconte
persons.context: Head of the Anti-Financial Crime and SARs department where Hill-McFadden was moved in 2017.

persons.name: Erin
persons.context: Present with Josh Blazer at Hill-McFadden's termination meeting.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deutsche Bank client. Hill-McFadden raised concerns about wires sent to young women and a woman in France. The team wanted to terminate his relationship.

persons.name: Darin Mcinke
persons.context: Jeffrey Epstein's lawyer. An internal SAR was filed on him in late 2016.

connections.description: Quigley was Hill-McFadden's supervisor. Hill-McFadden alleges Quigley was incompetent, retaliated against her for raising compliance issues, and intentionally rejected her work.
Salit was a senior director above Quigley. Hill-McFadden emailed him about Quigley's retaliation, but he did not respond. He was involved in decisions regarding flagged accounts.
Wang sat next to Quigley in New York and was the person who placed 102 PEP cases into deferred status, which Hill-McFadden believed Quigley knew about.
Acedebo, as Director of AFC, consistently supported Quigley and Salit, allowing Quigley to continue writing Hill-McFadden's reviews despite known conflicts.
Rose was the Relationship Manager for Kushner's company, Real Contrad, LLC. She contacted the client directly about suspicious transactions, contrary to policy.
Rose was also the Relationship Manager for Jeffrey Epstein's accounts at Deutsche Bank.
Mcinke is identified as Epstein's lawyer. An internal SAR was filed on him.
Hill-McFadden reviewed Epstein's accounts, raised concerns about suspicious wires, and requested to stop working on them.
Hill-McFadden flagged suspicious cryptocurrency activity in Kushner's company account and recommended it be closed.

events.title: Discovery of 102 Deferred PEP Cases
events.description: Tammy Hill-McFadden, using a formula from Clarrisa Delafuente, discovered 102 Politically Exposed Persons (PEP) cases in 'deferred' status in Deutsche Bank's system, which she believed was improper for high-risk clients.

events.title: HR Investigation into Quigley
events.description: After Hill-McFadden reported Sheri Quigley's alleged retaliation to HR (Francesca Benson), an investigation was opened. It concluded approximately a year later with a finding of no wrongdoing.

events.title: Review of Jared Kushner's Real Contrad Account
events.description: Hill-McFadden reviewed transactions for Real Contrad, LLC, owned by Jared Kushner, finding suspicious cryptocurrency activity. She recommended closing the accounts, but the case was closed after the Relationship Manager contacted the client.

events.title: Concerns Raised About Jeffrey Epstein's Accounts
events.description: Hill-McFadden raised concerns about Jeffrey Epstein's accounts, noting wires to young women and a woman in France. She emailed Sheri Quigley requesting to stop working on the accounts, but Quigley replied that Epstein had served his time and the accounts remained open.

events.title: SAR Filed on Epstein's Lawyer
events.description: An internal Suspicious Activity Report was filed on Jeffrey Epstein's lawyer, Darin Mcinke. Hill-McFadden learned of it while the Federal Reserve was present at the bank with Sheri Quigley.

events.title: Termination of Tammy Hill-McFadden
events.description: Hill-McFadden was terminated by Deutsche Bank. The meeting was conducted by Josh Blazer and an individual named Erin, who cited low productivity and performance but did not provide full documentation.

events.title: FBI Interview of Tammy Hill-McFadden
events.description: Hill-McFadden was interviewed by the FBI at the Jacksonville, FL field office, with her attorneys present, regarding her experiences and allegations about Deutsche Bank's compliance failures.

keyFacts: Tammy Hill-McFadden, a former Deutsche Bank AML officer, alleges the bank's compliance department failed to properly monitor high-risk clients, including Jeffrey Epstein, Jared Kushner, and Donald Trump.
Hill-McFadden discovered 102 Politically Exposed Persons (PEP) cases improperly placed in 'deferred' status, which she believed was known to her supervisor, Sheri Quigley.
Hill-McFadden raised specific concerns about Jeffrey Epstein's accounts, noting wires to young women, but was told by Quigley that Epstein had 'served his time' and the accounts remained open.
Hill-McFadden flagged suspicious cryptocurrency transactions in an LLC owned by Jared Kushner, but after the Relationship Manager contacted the client, the case was closed without action.

Hill-McFadden alleges she faced severe retaliation from supervisor Sheri Quigley, including rejected work and a damaged performance review, after raising these compliance issues, ultimately leading to her termination in 2018.
